<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will determine the acceleration of free fall \(g\) using a pendulum. Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1 and Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[175, 112, 819, 325]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[272, 336, 339, 355]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[583, 336, 653, 355]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 367, 593, 386]]<|/det|>
A pendulum has been set up for you as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 397, 146, 416]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 397, 920, 432]]<|/det|>
Adjust the length of the pendulum until the distance \(d\) measured to the centre of the bob is \(50.0 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 443, 920, 478]]<|/det|>
Displace the bob slightly and release it so that it swings. Fig. 1.2 shows one complete oscillation of the pendulum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 490, 181, 509]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 490, 584, 509]]<|/det|>
Measure the time \(t\) for 10 complete oscillations.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[559, 521, 920, 541]]<|/det|>
<form>t = ....................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 553, 181, 572]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 553, 920, 587]]<|/det|>
Calculate the period \(T\) of the pendulum. The period is the time for one complete oscillation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 644, 920, 664]]<|/det|>
<form>T = ............................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 676, 181, 695]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 676, 306, 695]]<|/det|>
Calculate \(T^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 752, 920, 772]]<|/det|>
<form>T^2 = ....................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 785, 181, 804]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 784, 734, 804]]<|/det|>
Calculate the acceleration of free fall \(g\) using the equation \(g = \frac{20}{T^2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 863, 920, 881]]<|/det|>
<form>g = ....................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 91]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 648, 89]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will determine the focal length \(f\) of a lens. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 571, 121]]<|/det|> Carry out the following instructions referring to Fig. 3.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 129, 878, 234]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 253, 532, 272]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 284, 146, 303]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[166, 284, 756, 303]]<|/det|> • Place the screen a distance \(D = 70.0 \text{cm}\) from the illuminated object. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 316, 178, 333]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 314, 920, 348]]<|/det|> Place the lens between the object and the screen so that the lens is very close to the screen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 362, 173, 380]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 361, 920, 394]]<|/det|> Move the lens slowly away from the screen until a clearly focused image is formed on the screen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 408, 181, 426]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[190, 408, 920, 441]]<|/det|> • Measure, and record in Table 3.1, the distance \(u\) between the centre of the lens and the illuminated object. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 454, 920, 488]]<|/det|> • Measure, and record in the table, the distance \(v\) between the centre of the lens and the screen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 501, 180, 519]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 501, 675, 519]]<|/det|> Calculate the product \(uv\). Record your answer in the table. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 532, 178, 551]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 532, 875, 549]]<|/det|> Repeat the procedure using values for \(D\) of \(75.0 \text{cm}\), \(80.0 \text{cm}\), \(85.0 \text{cm}\) and \(90.0 \text{cm}\). <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 562, 539, 580]]<|/det|> Table 3.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[255, 588, 740, 794]]<|/det|>
\(D/\text{cm}\)\(u/\text{cm}\)\(v/\text{cm}\)\(uv/\text{cm}^2\)
70.0
75.0
80.0
85.0
90.0
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 795, 920, 814]]<|/det|> [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
A student is investigating the effect of double-walled insulation on the rate of cooling of hot water in a copper container. The student places the copper container inside a larger metal container. He is investigating the effect of the size of the air gap between the copper container and larger metal containers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 920, 183]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate the effect of the size of the air gap between the copper container and larger metal containers on the rate of cooling of hot water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 197, 420, 214]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 228, 314, 244]]<|/det|>
a copper container

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 247, 883, 264]]<|/det|>
a number of metal containers of different diameters (all larger than the copper container)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 268, 281, 284]]<|/det|>
a thermometer

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 288, 260, 304]]<|/det|>
a stopwatch

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 308, 331, 324]]<|/det|>
a measuring cylinder

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 329, 334, 345]]<|/det|>
a supply of hot water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 359, 907, 376]]<|/det|>
You can also use other apparatus and materials that are usually available in a school laboratory.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 390, 536, 406]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to carry out this investigation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 420, 324, 437]]<|/det|>
In your plan, you should:

<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 514, 920, 547]]<|/det|>
draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how you would display your readings (you are not required to enter any readings in the table)
